item.title: Triads on different strings
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: This is part 2 of a 2-part series on triads: Triad Introduction Triads on other strings (this page) Triads exist on more than just the top three strings, of course. The shapes change slightly on each different course of three strings because of the way the guitar is tuned. The best way to learn these additional shapes is using what Josh at Fretboard Anatomy calls “Octave Drop Chord Building.

item.title: Triads
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: This is part 1 of a 2-part series on triads: Triad Introduction (this page) Triads on other strings Chords are just multiple notes played simultaneously. Technically, you can have two-note chords (AKA dyads) but most people consider three-note chords (called “triads”) to be the simplest possible place to start making real chord harmonies. Triads are formed by “stacking” intervals of a minor or major 3rd on top of each other.
